Exercise

What is the Taylor series of \(\dfrac{1}{1-x}\) about \(x=2\). (That is, find a power series in powers of \((x-2)\).)

generalfeedback.text: First, obtain the first three derivatives and the \(n^{\text{th}}\) derivative of \(f(x)=\dfrac{1}{1-x}\): \[f'(x)=\dfrac{1}{(1-x)^2},\qquad f''(x)=\dfrac{2}{(1-x)^3},\qquad f'''(x)=\dfrac{6}{(1-x)^4},\qquad \cdots \quad f^{(n)}(x)=\dfrac{n!}{(1-x)^{n+1}}\] Now evaluate these derivatives at \(x_0=2\): \[f'(2)=1,\qquad f''(2)=-2,\qquad f'''(2)=6,\qquad f^{(n)}(2)=(-1)^{n+1}n!\] Hence, write down the Taylor expansion of \(f(x)=\dfrac{1}{1-x}\) about \(x=2\): \[\dfrac{1}{1-x}=-1+(x-2)-(x-2)^2+(x-2)^3+\cdots + (-1)^{n+1}(x-2)^n+\cdots\]
